Authors:
Meijiao Zhou, Jinhua Xiao, Shengnan Bian, Yanwei Li, Liming
Niu, Haoyuan Hu, Wenshan Wu, Robert W. Murphy, Dawei Huang
Title:
Molecular approaches identify known species, reveal cryptic
species, and verify host specificity of Chinese Philotrypesis
(Hymenoptera: Pteromalidae)
Keywords:
sexual dimorphism; male polymorphism; gender association;
fig wasp; DNA barcoding
Abstract:
Philotrypesis, a major component of the fig wasp community
(Hymenoptera: Pteromalidae), is a model taxon for studying male fighting
and mating behavior. Its extreme sexual dimorphism and male polymorphism
render species identification uncertain and in-depth research on its
ecology, behavior and other evolutionary topics challenging. The fig
waspsâ enclosed habitat within the syconia makes their mating behavior
inaccessible, and to the extent of matching conspecific females and
males. In this study, we combine morphological and molecular analyses to
identify species of Philotrypesis sampled from south China, and to
associate their extraordinarily dimorphic genders, and labile male
morphologies. Morphological evaluations of females identify 22 species
and 28 male morphs. The mitochondrial COI and nuclear ITS2 data detect
21 species using females, and 15 species among the males. Most of the
males well match the species as delimited by females. Both markers
affirm reveal cryptic species in P. quadrisetosa on Ficus vasculosa.
Most species of wasps live on one species of fig but three species
co-occur in two hosts (F. microcarpa and F. benjamina), which indicates
host switching.
